moves.1. b4: !? Intending to fianchetto the dark-squared bishop, but instead of the more solid 1.b3 White also intends to gain space on the queenside.
moves.1... a5: I will try to prove that 1.b4 creates unnecessary weaknesses.
moves.2... d5: I will develop like a normal London System, and try to exploit the extra weaknesses in White's base.
moves.3. Bb2: Following through with the plan of posting bishop where it controls the most squares.
moves.3... Bf5: Classic move of the London System. Get The bishop outside of the pawn chain before playing e6
moves.4. e3: Boosting control of d4, while also defending b5.
moves.5... e6 6. cxd5 exd5: I end up losing a central pawn for a flank pawn, but it is OK, because White is creating weaknesses with every additional pawn advance. I also get an open e-file for my rook if I need it.
moves.7. a4: creating additional weaknesses in order to over-defend b5
moves.8. Nf3: Improving control of the central dark squares. Very similar to a Queen's Indian, except that White has pushed the a & b-pawns further than normal.
moves.8... Bd6 9. Nc3 O-O 10. Be2 h6: Creating luft for the bishop/king like in a normal London System.
moves.12... c6: With prospects for a future kingside attack with the Queen/Bishop battery along the b8-h2 diagonal.
moves.13... bxc6: now I have prospects on the queenside with my open-file, in the center with my control of the light-squares, and on the kingside with my open e-file and control of the b8-h2 diagonal.
moves.14. O-O: The f3-knight already defends h2, and I didn't see anything immediately decisive in the center,
moves.14... Na6: Aiming to re-position the knight on the b4-outpost, where it cannot be chased away by pawns, it can only be attacked by pieces, in which I can replace b4 while improving something else.
moves.15. Ba3: White could have tried this idea earlier.
moves.16. Bxb4: This trade is usually only good in a closed position, not an open one.
moves.17... c5: This weakens b5, but I thought it is OK now that the knight cannot take advantage of the b5 outpost
moves.18. Bb5: a bishop on an outpost is not the same. bishop's do not belong in a knight's role
moves.19. d4: blocking the a1-h8 diagonal now that there is no bishop to obstruct
moves.19... c4: but I advance with 2 connected passed pawns
moves.20... dxc4 21. Qxc4: White has 2 connected passed pawns for the piece, but the a-pawn is isolated, and I have superior piece placement and the bishop pair.
moves.22... Bh3: Takes advantage of those weaknesses. This time a bishop is appropriate for this task, because it is a kingside assault.
moves.23. Nb2: intends to be down a full rook
moves.23... Rfc8: I decided to develop more instead of taking rook
moves.24. Rfc1 Ne4: taking advantage of the d4-pawn advance, now there is no d3. I am also targeting f2, which has been weakened by the rook's movement.
moves.25. Nd3: controlling f2 and c5 and e5
moves.25... Qf6: targetting f3 & f2, and revealing the bishop to g3
moves.27. Qxc8+: White decides to give up the queen
moves.27... Bxc8: two rooks are redundant, so I decided to leave White with 2 rooks.
moves.28. hxg3: I have queen for rook and pawn
moves.30. Rc4 Qh5 31. Nh4 g5: kicking knight from stopping my plan
moves.32. d5: gxh4 followed by hxg3 and Qh3+
